On the best possible exponent for the error term in the lattice point counting problem on the first Heisenberg group

Yoav A. Gath
Faculty of Mathematics
Technion, Israel Institute Of Technology
Abstract

We use classical methods from analytic number theory to resolve the lattice point counting problem on the first Heisenberg group, in the case where the gauge function is taken to be the Cygan-Kora´´𝑎\acute{a}nyi Heisenberg-norm 𝒩4,1​(z,w)=(|z|4+w2)1/4subscript𝒩41𝑧𝑤superscriptsuperscript𝑧4superscript𝑤214\mathcal{N}_{4,1}(z,w)=(|z|^{4}+w^{2})^{1/4}. In this case, our main theorem establishes the estimate ℰ​(x)=Ω±​(x12)ℰ𝑥subscriptΩplus-or-minussuperscript𝑥12\mathcal{E}(x)=\Omega_{\pm}(x^{\frac{1}{2}}), where ℰ​(x)=𝒮​(x)−π22​xℰ𝑥𝒮𝑥superscript𝜋22𝑥\mathcal{E}(x)=\mathcal{S}(x)-\frac{\pi^{2}}{2}x is the error term arising in the lattice point counting problem, 𝒮​(x)𝒮𝑥\mathcal{S}(x) is given by

𝒮​(x)=∑0≤m2+n2<xr2​(m)𝒮𝑥subscript0superscript𝑚2superscript𝑛2𝑥subscript𝑟2𝑚\mathcal{S}(x)=\sum_{0\leq m^{2}+n^{2}<\,x}r_{2}(m)

and r2​(m)=|{a,b∈ℤ:a2+b2=m}|subscript𝑟2𝑚conditional-set𝑎𝑏ℤsuperscript𝑎2superscript𝑏2𝑚r_{2}(m)=|\{a,b\in\mathbb{Z}:\,a^{2}+b^{2}=m\}| is the familiar sum of squares function. As a corollary, we deduce that the exponent 1212\frac{1}{2} in the upper-bound |ℰ​(x)|≪x12​log⁡xmuch-less-thanℰ𝑥superscript𝑥12𝑥\left|\mathcal{E}(x)\right|\ll x^{\frac{1}{2}}\log{x} obtained by Garg, Nevo & Taylor can not be improved and is thus best possible, thereby resolving the lattice point counting problem for the case in hand.

1 Introduction, notation and statement of results

1.1 General counting principles

Counting lattice points in Euclidean space. Given a region ℬ⊂ℝnℬsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathcal{B}\subset\mathbb{R}^{n}, the problem of estimating the number of integral points in large homothetic regions |ℤn∩t​ℬ|superscriptℤ𝑛𝑡ℬ|\mathbb{Z}^{n}\cap t\mathcal{B}| has a long history which can be traced back to Gauss and Dirichlet. Under suitable assumptions on ℬℬ\mathcal{B}, we expect the quantity |ℤn∩t​ℬ|superscriptℤ𝑛𝑡ℬ|\mathbb{Z}^{n}\cap t\mathcal{B}| to be well approximated by λ​(t​ℬ)𝜆𝑡ℬ\lambda(t\mathcal{B}) == vol(tℬℬ\mathcal{B}), and we measure the resulting discrepancy arising from this approximation by analyzing the error term ℰ​(t)=|ℤn∩t​ℬ|−λ​(t​ℬ)ℰ𝑡superscriptℤ𝑛𝑡ℬ𝜆𝑡ℬ\mathcal{E}(t)=|\mathbb{Z}^{n}\cap t\mathcal{B}|-\lambda(t\mathcal{B}). To get a handle on the error term, we introduce the notion of an admissible exponent. Say α𝛼\alpha is an admissible exponent if one has the estimate |ℰ​(t)|≪ϵ(λ​(t​ℬ))α+ϵsubscriptmuch-less-thanitalic-ϵℰ𝑡superscript𝜆𝑡ℬ𝛼italic-ϵ\big{|}\mathcal{E}(t)\big{|}\ll_{\epsilon}(\lambda(t\mathcal{B}))^{\alpha+\epsilon} for any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, as t→∞→𝑡t\to\infty. Setting κ=infα𝜅subscriptinfimum𝛼\kappa=\inf_{\alpha}, where the infimum is taken over all admissible exponents, the (Euclidean) lattice point counting problem is that of establishing an asymptotic estimate of the form

|ℤn∩t​ℬ|=λ​(t​ℬ)+𝒪ϵ​(λ​(t​ℬ))κ+ϵsuperscriptℤ𝑛𝑡ℬ𝜆𝑡ℬsubscript𝒪italic-ϵsuperscript𝜆𝑡ℬ𝜅italic-ϵ|\mathbb{Z}^{n}\cap t\mathcal{B}|=\lambda(t\mathcal{B})+\mathcal{O}_{\epsilon}(\lambda(t\mathcal{B}))^{\kappa+\epsilon} (1.1)

For any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0.

Below we list three motivating examples which have played an important role in the development of this subject.
∙∙\bullet Euclidean balls. In ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2} one has κ≤131416𝜅131416\kappa\leq\frac{131}{416} due to Huxley [12], while the conjectured value is κ=14𝜅14\kappa=\frac{1}{4}. In ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3} one has κ≤2148𝜅2148\kappa\leq\frac{21}{48} due to Heath-Brown [9], while the conjectured value is κ=13𝜅13\kappa=\frac{1}{3}. For n≥4𝑛4n\geq 4, the value of κ𝜅\kappa has been obtained, and its value is κ=1−2n𝜅12𝑛\kappa=1-\frac{2}{n}. For more details we refer the reader to [19].
∙∙\bullet Euclidean dilates of smooth compact convex bodies in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n} whose boundary surface has everywhere non-vanishing Gaussian curvature. These include amongst others, ellipsoids and other bodies of revolution, and for the relevant results on the error estimates we refer the reader to [11], [10], [1] and [13].
∙∙\bullet Euclidean dilates of bodies in ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n} whose boundary surface contains points of vanishing Gaussian curvature. This is a difficult case, and in general very little is known, except for a handful of special cases such as the unit balls of lpsuperscript𝑙𝑝l^{p}-norm and some generalizations. For these cases, the effect of vanishing curvature on the error estimates has been extensively investigated, and we refer the reader to [16], [17], and [18].

The lattice point counting problem that we shall consider in the present paper will take a similar form to that of (1.1), the crucial difference being the dilation used in the expansion process. Our interest in this change of setting is motivated by viewing our lattice point counting problem in a wider context, as we now explain.

Counting points in lattice subgroups. In view of (1.1), it is natural to consider the following considerably more general set-up. Suppose 𝐆⊂𝐆𝐋n𝐆subscript𝐆𝐋𝑛\mathbf{G}\subset\mathbf{GL}_{n} is a connected linear algebraic group defined over ℚℚ\mathbb{Q} such that Γ=𝐆​(ℤ)Γ𝐆ℤ\Gamma=\mathbf{G}(\mathbb{Z}), its collection of integral points, forms a lattice subgroup in the group G=𝐆​(ℝ)⊂𝐆𝐋n​(ℝ)G𝐆ℝsubscript𝐆𝐋𝑛ℝ\textit{G}=\mathbf{G}(\mathbb{R})\subset\mathbf{GL}_{n}(\mathbb{R}) of real points. Let ℬt⊂Gsubscriptℬ𝑡G\mathcal{B}_{t}\subset\textit{G} be a family of bounded Borel subsets parameterized by t∈ℝ+𝑡subscriptℝt\in\mathbb{R}_{+} satisfying μ​(ℬt)→∞→𝜇subscriptℬ𝑡\mu(\mathcal{B}_{t})\to\infty, where μ𝜇\mu denotes the Haar measure on G normalized so to have measure 111 on a fundamental domain of ΓΓ\Gamma in G. In analogy with the Euclidean case, one aims to establish an asymptotic estimate of the form

|Γ∩ℬt|=μ​(ℬt)+𝒪ϵ​(μ​(ℬt))κ+ϵΓsubscriptℬ𝑡𝜇subscriptℬ𝑡subscript𝒪italic-ϵsuperscript𝜇subscriptℬ𝑡𝜅italic-ϵ|\Gamma\cap\mathcal{B}_{t}|=\mu(\mathcal{B}_{t})+\mathcal{O}_{\epsilon}(\mu(\mathcal{B}_{t}))^{\kappa+\epsilon} (1.2)

for any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, where κ𝜅\kappa is taken to be the infimum over all admissible exponents.

There are numerous methods to construct interesting families ℬt⊂Gsubscriptℬ𝑡G\mathcal{B}_{t}\subset\textit{G}. One such method, which is the one we shall adopt, is to consider a gauge ω𝜔\omega defined on G, i.e a left-invariant pseudo-distance function, and then take ℬt={g∈G:ω​(g,e)<t}subscriptℬ𝑡conditional-set𝑔G𝜔𝑔𝑒𝑡\mathcal{B}_{t}=\{g\in\textit{G}:\omega(g,e)<t\}. Of particular interest is the case where the gauge is taken to be a (proper) left-invariant distance function. In this direction, let us mention that (1.2) has never been established, even in a single case, for any left-invariant distance function on any non-compact simple Lie group. For more details, as well as for other interesting examples and related results on the error terms, we refer the reader to [8].

In the present paper we intend to establish (1.2) for the case of the first Heisenberg group, where the gauge is taken to be the Cygan-Kora´´𝑎\acute{a}nyi Heisenberg-norm. In fact, we shall first state the lattice point counting problem on an arbitrary Heisenberg group with respect to a certain family of gauges. This family, consisting of the so called Heisenberg-norms, arises naturally through the action of the dilation and unitary groups, and was considered in [7] where the reader may find an in-depth and broad treatment of the lattice point counting problem on the Heisenberg groups.

We now turn to describe the set-up for the lattice point counting problem considered in [7], and we shall do so in the context of (1.2). Thus, for the time being we consider an Heisenberg group of arbitrary dimension along with any Heisenberg norm defined on it.

I would like to express my deepest gratitude to my advisor Prof. Amos Nevo for his support and guidance throughout the writing of this paper.

1.2 Counting lattice points on the Heisenberg group

The Heisenberg group. The q𝑞q-th Heisenberg group ℋqsubscriptℋ𝑞\mathcal{H}_{q} has several equivalent descriptions, one of which is given by

ℋq=ℝq×ℝq×ℝ={(x,y,w):x,y∈ℝq,w∈ℝ}subscriptℋ𝑞superscriptℝ𝑞superscriptℝ𝑞ℝconditional-set𝑥𝑦𝑤formulae-sequence𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ𝑞𝑤ℝ\mathcal{H}_{q}=\mathbb{R}^{q}\times\mathbb{R}^{q}\times\mathbb{R}=\{(x,y,w):\,x,y\in\mathbb{R}^{q},\,w\in\ \mathbb{R}\} (1.3)

where the group law is defined by

(x,y,w)​(x′,y′,w′)=(x+x′,y+y′,w+w′+⟨x,y′⟩),𝑥𝑦𝑤superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′superscript𝑤′𝑥superscript𝑥′𝑦superscript𝑦′𝑤superscript𝑤′𝑥superscript𝑦′(x,y,w)(x^{\prime},y^{\prime},w^{\prime})=(x+x^{\prime},y+y^{\prime},w+w^{\prime}+\langle x,y^{\prime}\rangle)\,,

and ⟨⋅,⋅⟩⋅⋅\langle\cdotp,\cdotp\rangle denotes the standard inner product on ℝqsuperscriptℝ𝑞\mathbb{R}^{q}.

An equivalent realization of ℋqsubscriptℋ𝑞\mathcal{H}_{q} is given by the isomorphic group

ℋq=ℂq×ℝ={(z,w):z=x+i​y∈ℂq,w∈ℝ}subscriptℋ𝑞superscriptℂ𝑞ℝconditional-set𝑧𝑤formulae-sequence𝑧𝑥𝑖𝑦superscriptℂ𝑞𝑤ℝ\mathcal{H}_{q}=\mathbb{C}^{q}\times\mathbb{R}=\{(z,w):\,z=x+iy\in\mathbb{C}^{q},\,w\in\ \mathbb{R}\} (1.4)

where the group law is defined by

(z,w)​(z′,w′)=(z+z′,w+w′+2​ℑ⁡(z⋅z′))𝑧𝑤superscript𝑧′superscript𝑤′𝑧superscript𝑧′𝑤superscript𝑤′2⋅𝑧superscript𝑧′(z,w)(z^{\prime},w^{\prime})=(z+z^{\prime},w+w^{\prime}+2\Im(z\cdotp z^{\prime}))

so that multiplication can also be described by the symplectic form:

(x,y,w)​(x′,y′,w′)=(x+x′,y+y′,w+w′+2​(⟨x′,y⟩−⟨x,y′⟩)).𝑥𝑦𝑤superscript𝑥′superscript𝑦′superscript𝑤′𝑥superscript𝑥′𝑦superscript𝑦′𝑤superscript𝑤′2superscript𝑥′𝑦𝑥superscript𝑦′(x,y,w)(x^{\prime},y^{\prime},w^{\prime})=(x+x^{\prime},y+y^{\prime},w+w^{\prime}+2(\langle x^{\prime},y\rangle-\langle x,y^{\prime}\rangle))\,.

Having defined ℋqsubscriptℋ𝑞\mathcal{H}_{q}, we proceed by introducing two important groups of automorphisms acting on it. The first is the dilation group, which is parameterized by

ℋq∋(z,w)↦ϕa​(z,w)=(a​z,a2​w),a∈ℝ+.formulae-sequencecontainssubscriptℋ𝑞𝑧𝑤maps-tosubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑎𝑧𝑤𝑎𝑧superscript𝑎2𝑤𝑎subscriptℝ\mathcal{H}_{q}\ni(z,w)\mapsto\phi_{a}(z,w)=(az,a^{2}w)\,\,,\,\,a\in\mathbb{R}_{+}\,.

The second group of automorphisms is given by the action of the unitary group 𝐔q​(ℂ)subscript𝐔𝑞ℂ\mathbf{U}_{q}(\mathbb{C}), where

ℋq∋(z,w)↦Φ𝒰​(z,w)=(𝒰​z,w),𝒰∈𝐔q​(ℂ).formulae-sequencecontainssubscriptℋ𝑞𝑧𝑤maps-tosubscriptΦ𝒰𝑧𝑤𝒰𝑧𝑤𝒰subscript𝐔𝑞ℂ\mathcal{H}_{q}\ni(z,w)\mapsto\Phi_{\mathcal{U}}(z,w)=(\mathcal{U}z,w)\,\,,\,\,\mathcal{U}\in\mathbf{U}_{q}(\mathbb{C})\,.

Heisenberg-norms. The action of the dilation group gives rise to the natural notion of homogeneity. Say ψ:ℋq→ℂ:𝜓→subscriptℋ𝑞ℂ\psi:\mathcal{H}_{q}\rightarrow\mathbb{C} is homogeneous of degree d𝑑d if

ψ∘ϕa=ad​ψ,for any​a∈ℝ+.formulae-sequence𝜓subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑎superscript𝑎𝑑𝜓for any𝑎subscriptℝ\psi\circ\phi_{a}=a^{d}\psi,\,\,\text{for any}\,\,a\in\mathbb{R}_{+}\,.

Likewise, the action of the unitary group gives rise to the natural notion of radiality, where we say that Ψ:ℋq→ℂ:Ψ→subscriptℋ𝑞ℂ\Psi:\mathcal{H}_{q}\rightarrow\mathbb{C} is radial if

Ψ∘Φ𝒰=Ψ,for any​𝒰∈𝐔q​(ℂ).formulae-sequenceΨsubscriptΦ𝒰Ψfor any𝒰subscript𝐔𝑞ℂ\Psi\circ\Phi_{\mathcal{U}}=\Psi,\,\,\text{for any}\,\,\mathcal{U}\in\mathbf{U}_{q}(\mathbb{C})\,.

Having the notion of homogeneity and radiality, we now turn to the definition of the Heisenberg-norms. These norms are parameterized by α,A>0𝛼𝐴0\alpha,A>0, and take the form

𝒩α,A​(z,w)=(|z|α+A​|w|α/2)1/α.subscript𝒩𝛼𝐴𝑧𝑤superscriptsuperscript𝑧𝛼𝐴superscript𝑤𝛼21𝛼\mathcal{N}_{\alpha,A}(z,w)=(|z|^{\alpha}+A|w|^{\alpha/2})^{1/\alpha}\,. (1.5)

It is evident that the Heisenberg-norms 𝒩α,Asubscript𝒩𝛼𝐴\mathcal{N}_{\alpha,A} are radial and homogeneous of degree 111. Of particular importance is the norm 𝒩4,1subscript𝒩41\mathcal{N}_{4,1}, the so called Cygan-Kora´´𝑎\acute{a}nyi Heisenberg-norm. This norm was considered by Cygan [6], [5] and Kora´´𝑎\acute{a}nyi [15]. Amongst its many properties, this gauge satisfies the inequality 𝒩4,1​(u⋅v)≤𝒩4,1​(u)+𝒩4,1​(v)subscript𝒩41⋅𝑢𝑣subscript𝒩41𝑢subscript𝒩41𝑣\mathcal{N}_{4,1}(u\cdotp v)\leq\mathcal{N}_{4,1}(u)+\mathcal{N}_{4,1}(v) for all u,v∈ℋq𝑢𝑣subscriptℋ𝑞u,v\in\mathcal{H}_{q}, making the map δ​(u,v)=𝒩4,1​(v−1⋅u)𝛿𝑢𝑣subscript𝒩41⋅superscript𝑣1𝑢\delta(u,v)=\mathcal{N}_{4,1}(v^{-1}\cdotp u) a left-invariant distance function. One may also find this norm appearing in the context of harmonic analysis on the Heisenberg group. For example, it appears in the expression defining the fundamental solution of a natural sublaplacian on the Heisenberg group and in other natural kernels, and we refer the reader to [21] and [4]. For us, the significance of the Cygan-Kora´´𝑎\acute{a}nyi Heisenberg-norm will be apparent through the use of Lemma 1 in the proof of the main theorem.

Counting lattice points inside Heisenberg-dilated bodies. Having the relevant notation and definitions at hand, we now proceed to describe the lattice point counting problem considered in [7]. Since ℋqsubscriptℋ𝑞\mathcal{H}_{q} is parameterized by ℝ2​q+1superscriptℝ2𝑞1\mathbb{R}^{2q+1}, its lattice subgroup of integral points is parameterized by ℤ2​q+1superscriptℤ2𝑞1\mathbb{Z}^{2q+1}, and for the Haar measure on ℋqsubscriptℋ𝑞\mathcal{H}_{q} we take the Lebesgue measure λ=λ2​q+1𝜆subscript𝜆2𝑞1\lambda=\lambda_{2q+1} on ℝ2​q+1superscriptℝ2𝑞1\mathbb{R}^{2q+1}. Next, for α,A>0𝛼𝐴0\alpha,A>0 we write ℬtα,A⊂ℝ2​q+1subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝛼𝐴𝑡superscriptℝ2𝑞1\mathcal{B}^{\alpha,A}_{t}\subset\mathbb{R}^{2q+1} for the 𝒩α,Asubscript𝒩𝛼𝐴\mathcal{N}_{\alpha,A} ball of radius t𝑡t in ℋqsubscriptℋ𝑞\mathcal{H}_{q}, which is also the Heisenberg dilate by t𝑡t of the unit ball

ℬtα,A=ϕt​(ℬ1α,A).subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝛼𝐴𝑡subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝛼𝐴1\mathcal{B}^{\alpha,A}_{t}=\phi_{t}(\mathcal{B}^{\alpha,A}_{1})\,.

Let us note that λ𝜆\lambda scales under dilations according to the homogeneous dimension, not the Euclidean dimension, so in particular

λ​(ℬtα,A)=t2​q+2​λ​(ℬ1α,A).𝜆subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝛼𝐴𝑡superscript𝑡2𝑞2𝜆subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝛼𝐴1\lambda(\mathcal{B}^{\alpha,A}_{t})=t^{2q+2}\lambda(\mathcal{B}^{\alpha,A}_{1})\,.

Thus, in the set-up of (1.2), the lattice point counting problem is that of establishing an asymptotic estimate of the form

|ℤ2​q+1∩ℬtα,A|=λ​(ℬtα,A)+𝒪ϵ​(λ​(ℬtα,A))κ+ϵsuperscriptℤ2𝑞1subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝛼𝐴𝑡𝜆subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝛼𝐴𝑡subscript𝒪italic-ϵsuperscript𝜆subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝛼𝐴𝑡𝜅italic-ϵ|\mathbb{Z}^{2q+1}\cap\mathcal{B}^{\alpha,A}_{t}|=\lambda(\mathcal{B}^{\alpha,A}_{t})+\mathcal{O}_{\epsilon}(\lambda(\mathcal{B}^{\alpha,A}_{t}))^{\kappa+\epsilon} (1.6)

for any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, where κ𝜅\kappa is taken to be the infimum over all admissible exponents. In (1.6), the involved parameters are assumed to be fixed so we do not display their dependence in the error term.

In view of (1.6), the counting problem on ℋqsubscriptℋ𝑞\mathcal{H}_{q} is that of counting integral points in the Euclidean lattice ℤ2​q+1superscriptℤ2𝑞1\mathbb{Z}^{2q+1} contained in the family of increasing bodies ϕt​(ℬ1α,A)=ℬtα,A⊂ℝ2​q+1subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝛼𝐴1subscriptsuperscriptℬ𝛼𝐴𝑡superscriptℝ2𝑞1\phi_{t}(\mathcal{B}^{\alpha,A}_{1})=\mathcal{B}^{\alpha,A}_{t}\subset\mathbb{R}^{2q+1} as t→∞→𝑡t\to\infty. Note that the Heisenberg dilations used to expand ℬ1α,Asubscriptsuperscriptℬ𝛼𝐴1\mathcal{B}^{\alpha,A}_{1} are materially different from the Euclidean dilations. Also, one needs to obtain a good understanding of the geometric properties of these bodies, as they play a crucial role in the analysis of the error term. For example, it turns out that ℬ1α,Asubscriptsuperscriptℬ𝛼𝐴1\mathcal{B}^{\alpha,A}_{1} is Euclidean convex if and only if α≥2𝛼2\alpha\geq 2, and its boundary surface contains points of vanishing Gaussian curvature for values of α≥2𝛼2\alpha\geq 2. For further details, we refer the reader to [7].

1.3 Statement of results

We shall now confine ourselves to the case of ℋ1subscriptℋ1\mathcal{H}_{1} where the norm will be taken to be the Cygan-Kora´´𝑎\acute{a}nyi Heisenberg-norm 𝒩4,1subscript𝒩41\mathcal{N}_{4,1}. In [7], the upper-bound κ≤12𝜅12\kappa\leq\frac{1}{2} has been established, and we shall prove the opposite inequality κ≥12𝜅12\kappa\geq\frac{1}{2}, thereby establishing (1.6) with the value of κ=12𝜅12\kappa=\frac{1}{2}. We begin by introducing some notations.

Given a parameter t≥1𝑡1t\geq 1, we have the following equality

|ℤ3∩ℬt4,1|=∑0≤m2+n2<t4r2​(m),superscriptℤ3subscriptsuperscriptℬ41𝑡subscript0superscript𝑚2superscript𝑛2superscript𝑡4subscript𝑟2𝑚|\mathbb{Z}^{3}\cap\mathcal{B}^{4,1}_{t}|=\sum_{0\leq m^{2}+n^{2}<\,t^{4}}r_{2}(m)\,,

where r2​(m)=|{a,b∈ℤ:a2+b2=m}|subscript𝑟2𝑚conditional-set𝑎𝑏ℤsuperscript𝑎2superscript𝑏2𝑚r_{2}(m)=|\{a,b\in\mathbb{Z}:\,a^{2}+b^{2}=m\}|.

Setting x=t4𝑥superscript𝑡4x=t^{4}, the counting problem is that of estimating the sum

𝒮​(x)=∑0≤m2+n2<xr2​(m).𝒮𝑥subscript0superscript𝑚2superscript𝑛2𝑥subscript𝑟2𝑚\mathcal{S}(x)=\sum_{0\leq m^{2}+n^{2}<\,x}r_{2}(m)\,. (1.7)

Since 𝒮​(x)∼π22​xsimilar-to𝒮𝑥superscript𝜋22𝑥\mathcal{S}(x)\sim\frac{\pi^{2}}{2}x (to see this, first execute the summation over the variable n𝑛n, and then proceed by applying partial summation), the error term takes the following form

ℰ​(x)=𝒮​(x)−π22​x.ℰ𝑥𝒮𝑥superscript𝜋22𝑥\mathcal{E}(x)=\mathcal{S}(x)-\frac{\pi^{2}}{2}x. (1.8)

We are now ready to state our main results.

Theorem 1.

With ℰ​(x)ℰ𝑥\mathcal{E}(x) as above, we have:

lim supx→∞ℰ​(x)x12=∞subscriptlimit-supremum→𝑥ℰ𝑥superscript𝑥12\limsup_{x\to\infty}\frac{\mathcal{E}(x)}{x^{\frac{1}{2}}}=\infty (1.9)
lim infx→∞ℰ​(x)x12=−∞subscriptlimit-infimum→𝑥ℰ𝑥superscript𝑥12\liminf_{x\to\infty}\frac{\mathcal{E}(x)}{x^{\frac{1}{2}}}=-\infty (1.10)

In [7], the upper-bound |ℰ​(x)|≪x12​log⁡xmuch-less-thanℰ𝑥superscript𝑥12𝑥\left|\mathcal{E}(x)\right|\ll x^{\frac{1}{2}}\log{x} has been established, hence as an immediate corollary we deduce:

Corollary.

The exponent 1212\frac{1}{2} in the upper-bound |ℰ​(x)|≪x12​log⁡xmuch-less-thanℰ𝑥superscript𝑥12𝑥\left|\mathcal{E}(x)\right|\ll x^{\frac{1}{2}}\log{x} obtained by Garg, Nevo & Taylor can not be improved and is thus best possible, thereby establishing (1.6) with the value of κ=12𝜅12\kappa=\frac{1}{2}.

On the method of proof. One may approach the sum 𝒮​(x)𝒮𝑥\mathcal{S}(x) in several ways, one of which is by first replacing the sharp cutoff function χ[0,x)subscript𝜒0𝑥\chi_{[0,x)} by an appropriately chosen smooth function of compact support, and then apply Poisson summation for the smoothed sum. The zero frequency gives rise to the main term, and one is left with estimating the tail. As we wish to retain the true order of magnitude of ℰ​(x)ℰ𝑥\mathcal{E}(x), we opt to choose a different approach as we now explain.

First we note that 2​ℳ​(x)2ℳ𝑥2\mathcal{M}(x) differs from 𝒮​(x)𝒮𝑥\mathcal{S}(x) by an amount of size at most 𝒪​(x12)𝒪superscript𝑥12\mathcal{O}(x^{\frac{1}{2}}), where

ℳ​(x)=∑0≤m≤xr2​(m)​(x−m2)12.ℳ𝑥subscript0𝑚𝑥subscript𝑟2𝑚superscript𝑥superscript𝑚212\mathcal{M}(x)=\sum_{0\leq m\leq\,\sqrt[]{x}}r_{2}(m)(x-m^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}}\,. (1.11)

Thus, our theorem will follow if we can prove that the error term arising from the approximation of ℳ​(x)ℳ𝑥\mathcal{M}(x) obeys the two sided estimate Ω±​(x12)subscriptΩplus-or-minussuperscript𝑥12\Omega_{\pm}(x^{\frac{1}{2}}).

The presence of (x−m2)12superscript𝑥superscript𝑚212(x-m^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}} in the above sum is more than welcome, as it serves as a smoothing factor. Already at this stage, by applying standard methods of contour integration one can establish the bound |ℰ​(x)|≪x12​(log⁡x)Cmuch-less-thanℰ𝑥superscript𝑥12superscript𝑥𝐶\left|\mathcal{E}(x)\right|\ll x^{\frac{1}{2}}(\log{x})^{C} for some constant C>0𝐶0C>0. By performing a more careful analysis, one could obtain a closed form expression for the error term arising in the estimation of (1.11), however it turns out to be difficult to extract any information as to its true order of magnitude. The reason behind this difficulty is that the variable of summation m𝑚m appears in (x−m2)12superscript𝑥superscript𝑚212(x-m^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}} with a squared factor. To see this more clearly, by Mellin inversion with σ>1𝜎1\sigma>1, we have

M​(x)=x+c2​π​i​∫(σ)Γ​(s2)Γ​(s+32)​xs+12​Z​(s)​𝑑s𝑀𝑥𝑥𝑐2𝜋𝑖subscript𝜎Γ𝑠2Γ𝑠32superscript𝑥𝑠12𝑍𝑠differential-d𝑠M(x)\,=\,\sqrt[]{x}+\frac{c}{2\pi i}\int_{(\sigma)}\frac{\Gamma(\frac{s}{2})}{\Gamma(\frac{s+3}{2})}x^{\frac{s+1}{2}}Z(s)ds (1.12)

for some constant c𝑐c, where

Z​(s)=∑m=1∞r2​(m)ms.𝑍𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑚1subscript𝑟2𝑚superscript𝑚𝑠Z(s)=\sum_{m=1}^{\infty}\frac{r_{2}(m)}{m^{s}}.

The Gamma factor in (1.12) does not match the one appearing in the functional equation for Z​(s)𝑍𝑠Z(s), and this will cause some complications later on. To make the Gamma factors match, we first use Lemma 1 stated below to remove this square factor, and only then do we proceed to the evaluation of (1.12), leading us to the following sum

𝒮​(x;n)=(−1)nn!​f(n)​(2​x12)​∑0≤m≤xr2​(m)​(x−m)n+12𝒮𝑥𝑛superscript1𝑛𝑛superscript𝑓𝑛2superscript𝑥12subscript0𝑚𝑥subscript𝑟2𝑚superscript𝑥𝑚𝑛12\mathcal{S}(\,\sqrt[]{x}\,;n)=\frac{(-1)^{n}}{n!}f^{(n)}(2x^{\frac{1}{2}})\sum_{0\leq m\leq\,\sqrt[]{x}}r_{2}(m)(\sqrt[]{x}-m)^{n+\frac{1}{2}} (1.13)

where f​(t)=t12𝑓𝑡superscript𝑡12f(t)=t^{\frac{1}{2}}, and n𝑛n runs through nonnegative integers .

The sum appearing in (1.13) will be handled by Lemma 2 stated below, and we shall estimate it within an error term of size 𝒪​(2−n​x14)𝒪superscript2𝑛superscript𝑥14\mathcal{O}(2^{-n}x^{\frac{1}{4}}) uniformly in n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1. The error term arising in the approximation of 𝒮​(x;0)𝒮𝑥0\mathcal{S}(\,\sqrt[]{x}\,;0) will obey the estimate Ω±​(x12)subscriptΩplus-or-minussuperscript𝑥12\Omega_{\pm}(x^{\frac{1}{2}}) which is exactly what we need. Having Lemmas 1 and 2 at our disposal, we proceed to the proof of Theorem 1.

2 Preparatory Lemmas

where

It remains to estimate the second term on the RHS of (2.13).

By repeated use of the functional equation for the Gamma function, we have

G​(s)=Γ​(s)​Γ​(32)Γ​(s+32)​∏k=1nk+12s+k+12=Γ​(s)​Γ​(32)Γ​(s+32)​∏k=1n11+sk+12𝐺𝑠Γ𝑠Γ32Γ𝑠32superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑛𝑘12𝑠𝑘12Γ𝑠Γ32Γ𝑠32superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑛11𝑠𝑘12G(s)=\frac{\Gamma(s)\Gamma(\frac{3}{2})}{\Gamma(s+\frac{3}{2})}\prod_{k=1}^{n}\frac{k+\frac{1}{2}}{s+k+\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{\Gamma(s)\Gamma(\frac{3}{2})}{\Gamma(s+\frac{3}{2})}\prod_{k=1}^{n}\frac{1}{1+\frac{s}{k+\frac{1}{2}}}

thus

|G​(s)|=|Γ​(s)​Γ​(32)Γ​(s+32)|​∏k=1n1|1+sk+12|.𝐺𝑠Γ𝑠Γ32Γ𝑠32superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑛11𝑠𝑘12|G(s)|=\bigg{|}\frac{\Gamma(s)\Gamma(\frac{3}{2})}{\Gamma(s+\frac{3}{2})}\bigg{|}\prod_{k=1}^{n}\frac{1}{|1+\frac{s}{k+\frac{1}{2}}|}\,.

where the first product appearing above may be empty in case n=2𝑛2n=2.

By (2.14), together with the bound

|Cn​∏k=3n11−12​k+1|≤2−nsubscript𝐶𝑛superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘3𝑛1112𝑘1superscript2𝑛\bigg{|}C_{n}\prod_{k=3}^{n}\frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{2k+1}}\bigg{|}\leq 2^{-n}

The integral appearing on the RHS of (2.15) is independent of n𝑛n and converges absolutely by (2.9), hence case 1 is proved.

Case 2: n=0,1𝑛01n=0,1.

To handle this case, we shall appeal to two estimates proved by K. Chandrasekharan and Raghavan Narasimhan. These estimates, which are a special case of a much greater theory, can be found in [2] and [3]. In order to state their results, we begin by setting up some notations.

For ϱ>0italic-ϱ0\varrho>0 and y>0𝑦0y>0, let Eϱ​(y)subscript𝐸italic-ϱ𝑦E_{\varrho}(y) be defined by

∑0≤m≤yr2​(m)​(y−m)ϱ=Γ​(ϱ+1)Γ​(ϱ+2)​π​yϱ+1+Eϱ​(y).subscript0𝑚𝑦subscript𝑟2𝑚superscript𝑦𝑚italic-ϱΓitalic-ϱ1Γitalic-ϱ2𝜋superscript𝑦italic-ϱ1subscript𝐸italic-ϱ𝑦\sum_{0\leq m\leq y}r_{2}(m)(y-m)^{\varrho}=\frac{\Gamma(\varrho+1)}{\Gamma(\varrho+2)}\pi y^{\varrho+1}+E_{\varrho}(y)\,. (2.16)

Chandrasekharan and Narasimhan have considered Eϱ~​(y)=Eϱ​(y)/Γ​(ϱ+1)~subscript𝐸italic-ϱ𝑦subscript𝐸italic-ϱ𝑦Γitalic-ϱ1\tilde{E_{\varrho}}(y)=E_{\varrho}(y)/\Gamma(\varrho+1) instead, but this will make no difference for us since we are interested in evaluating (2.16) only for the values ϱ=12,32italic-ϱ1232\varrho=\frac{1}{2},\frac{3}{2}. Thus, the dependency of the forthcoming estimates with respect to the variable ϱitalic-ϱ\varrho will not concern us. In order to be consistent with [2], we shall state their results in terms of Eϱ~​(y)~subscript𝐸italic-ϱ𝑦\tilde{E_{\varrho}}(y). With the above notation, we have the following estimates (see [2] P.502 case (iii))

|Eϱ~​(y)|≪y12​(ϱ+12)much-less-than~subscript𝐸italic-ϱ𝑦superscript𝑦12italic-ϱ12|\tilde{E_{\varrho}}(y)|\ll y^{\frac{1}{2}(\varrho+\frac{1}{2})} (2.17)

provided ϱ>12italic-ϱ12\varrho>\frac{1}{2} where the implied constant may depend on ϱitalic-ϱ\varrho, while for ϱ≤12italic-ϱ12\varrho\leq\frac{1}{2} we have

lim supy→∞y−12​(ϱ+12)​Eϱ~​(y)=∞,lim infy→∞y−12​(ϱ+12)​Eϱ~​(y)=−∞.formulae-sequencesubscriptlimit-supremum→𝑦superscript𝑦12italic-ϱ12~subscript𝐸italic-ϱ𝑦subscriptlimit-infimum→𝑦superscript𝑦12italic-ϱ12~subscript𝐸italic-ϱ𝑦\limsup_{y\to\infty}y^{-\frac{1}{2}(\varrho+\frac{1}{2})}\tilde{E_{\varrho}}(y)=\infty,\,\,\,\liminf_{y\to\infty}y^{-\frac{1}{2}(\varrho+\frac{1}{2})}\tilde{E_{\varrho}}(y)=-\infty\,. (2.18)

Now we specialize to our case in hand, namely y=x𝑦𝑥y=\,\sqrt[]{x} and ϱ=n+12italic-ϱ𝑛12\varrho=n+\frac{1}{2} with n=0,1𝑛01n=0,1.

Writing

∑0≤m≤xr2​(m)​(x−m)n+12=πn+32​xn2+34+En+12​(x)subscript0𝑚𝑥subscript𝑟2𝑚superscript𝑥𝑚𝑛12𝜋𝑛32superscript𝑥𝑛234subscript𝐸𝑛12𝑥\sum_{0\leq m\leq\,\sqrt[]{x}}r_{2}(m)(\sqrt[]{x}-m)^{n+\frac{1}{2}}=\frac{\pi}{n+\frac{3}{2}}x^{\frac{n}{2}+\frac{3}{4}}+E_{n+\frac{1}{2}}(\,\sqrt[]{x\,}\,) (2.19)

we have by (2.17) and (2.18) the following estimates

|E32​(x)|≪x12much-less-thansubscript𝐸32𝑥superscript𝑥12|E_{\frac{3}{2}}(\,\sqrt[]{x\,}\,)|\ll\,x^{\frac{1}{2}} (2.20)
lim supx→∞x−14​E12​(x)=∞,lim infx→∞x−14​E12​(x)=−∞formulae-sequencesubscriptlimit-supremum→𝑥superscript𝑥14subscript𝐸12𝑥subscriptlimit-infimum→𝑥superscript𝑥14subscript𝐸12𝑥\limsup_{x\to\infty}x^{-\frac{1}{4}}E_{\frac{1}{2}}(\,\sqrt[]{x\,}\,)=\infty,\,\,\,\liminf_{x\to\infty}x^{-\frac{1}{4}}E_{\frac{1}{2}}(\,\sqrt[]{x\,}\,)=-\infty (2.21)

Note that by partial summation we have the easy bound

|E12​(x)|≪x12.much-less-thansubscript𝐸12𝑥superscript𝑥12\big{|}E_{\frac{1}{2}}(\,\sqrt[]{x\,}\,)\big{|}\ll x^{\frac{1}{2}}\,. (2.22)

where c1=−π5​2subscript𝑐1𝜋52c_{1}=-\frac{\pi}{5\,\sqrt[]{2}}, while for n=0𝑛0n=0 we have

𝒮​(x;0)=c0​x+2​x14​E12​(x)=c0​x+x12​Q​(x)𝒮𝑥0subscript𝑐0𝑥2superscript𝑥14subscript𝐸12𝑥subscript𝑐0𝑥superscript𝑥12𝑄𝑥\mathcal{S}(\,\sqrt[]{x}\,;0)=c_{0}x+\sqrt[]{2}x^{\frac{1}{4}}E_{\frac{1}{2}}(\,\sqrt[]{x\,}\,)=c_{0}x+x^{\frac{1}{2}}Q(\,\sqrt[]{x}\,) (2.24)

and

Thus case 2 is proved. ∎

3 Proof of Theorem 1

Proof (Theorem 1).
𝒮​(x)=∑0≤m2+n2<xr2​(m)=2​ℳ​(x)+𝒪​(x)𝒮𝑥subscript0superscript𝑚2superscript𝑛2𝑥subscript𝑟2𝑚2ℳ𝑥𝒪𝑥\mathcal{S}(x)=\sum_{0\leq m^{2}+n^{2}<\,x}r_{2}(m)=2\mathcal{M}(x)+\mathcal{O}(\,\sqrt[]{x}\,) (3.1)

where

ℳ​(x)=∑0≤m≤xr2​(m)​(x−m2)12.ℳ𝑥subscript0𝑚𝑥subscript𝑟2𝑚superscript𝑥superscript𝑚212\mathcal{M}(x)=\sum_{0\leq m\leq\,\sqrt[]{x}}r_{2}(m)(x-m^{2})^{\frac{1}{2}}\,.

Using Lemma 1, and switching the order of summation, we have

ℳ​(x)=∑n=0∞𝒮​(x;n).ℳ𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑛0𝒮𝑥𝑛\mathcal{M}(x)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\mathcal{S}(\,\sqrt[]{x}\,;n)\,. (3.2)

Setting

c=∑n=0∞cn𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑛0subscript𝑐𝑛c=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}c_{n}

where the sum clearly converges (see (2.2)), we have by Lemma 2 (2.1), (2.3)

ℳ​(x)=c​x+x12​Q​(x)+𝒪​(x14).ℳ𝑥𝑐𝑥superscript𝑥12𝑄𝑥𝒪superscript𝑥14\mathcal{M}(x)=cx+x^{\frac{1}{2}}Q(\,\sqrt[]{x}\,)+\mathcal{O}(x^{\frac{1}{4}})\,. (3.3)

Inserting (3.3) back into (3.1), we derive

S​(x)=2​c​x+2​x12​Q​(x)+𝒪​(x12).𝑆𝑥2𝑐𝑥2superscript𝑥12𝑄𝑥𝒪superscript𝑥12S(x)=2cx+2x^{\frac{1}{2}}Q(\,\sqrt[]{x}\,)+\mathcal{O}(x^{\frac{1}{2}})\,. (3.4)

By (2.5), the second term appearing on the RHS of (3.4) is bounded by x34superscript𝑥34x^{\frac{3}{4}}, and since 𝒮​(x)∼π22​xsimilar-to𝒮𝑥superscript𝜋22𝑥\mathcal{S}(x)\sim\frac{\pi^{2}}{2}x as x→∞→𝑥x\to\infty, it follows that 2​c=π222𝑐superscript𝜋222c=\frac{\pi^{2}}{2}.
Subtracting π22​xsuperscript𝜋22𝑥\frac{\pi^{2}}{2}x from both sides of (3.4), and dividing throughout by x12superscript𝑥12x^{\frac{1}{2}}, we arrive at

ℰ​(x)x12=2​Q​(x)+𝒪​(1).ℰ𝑥superscript𝑥122𝑄𝑥𝒪1\frac{\mathcal{E}(x)}{x^{\frac{1}{2}}}=2Q(\,\sqrt[]{x}\,)+\mathcal{O}(1)\,. (3.5)

Taking lim suplimit-supremum\limsup and lim inflimit-infimum\liminf, and using (2.4), concludes the proof. ∎

Concluding remarks. Our results remain valid in the case where the norm is taken to be 𝒩4,Asubscript𝒩4𝐴\mathcal{N}_{4,A} for any A>0𝐴0A>0, as long as we consider this variable to be fixed. If we where to allow A𝐴A to vary with x𝑥x, then the question of uniformity comes into play, and it would be an interesting problem to consider. Likewise, one may consider the lattice point counting problem when one or both of the variables of summation are restricted by congruence conditions to various moduli which are allowed to vary with x𝑥x. It should be mentioned though, that the value of α=4𝛼4\alpha=4 was crucial to our arguments for obtaining the desired Ω±subscriptΩplus-or-minus\Omega_{\pm} estimates, while for different values we would have to settle for upper-bounds.

Let us now say a few words about higher dimensional Heisenberg groups, where the norm is still the Cygan-Kora´´𝑎\acute{a}nyi Heisenberg-norm. As in the case of ℋ1subscriptℋ1\mathcal{H}_{1}, the sum under consideration takes the form

𝒮q​(x)=∑0≤m2+n2<xr2​q​(m)=∑l<xρq​(l)subscript𝒮𝑞𝑥subscript0superscript𝑚2superscript𝑛2𝑥subscript𝑟2𝑞𝑚subscript𝑙𝑥subscript𝜌𝑞𝑙\mathcal{S}_{q}(x)=\sum_{0\leq m^{2}+n^{2}<\,x}r_{2q}(m)=\sum_{l<\,x}\rho_{q}(l)

where

ρq​(l)=∑m2+n2=lr2​q​(m).subscript𝜌𝑞𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑚2superscript𝑛2𝑙subscript𝑟2𝑞𝑚\rho_{q}(l)=\sum_{m^{2}+n^{2}=l}r_{2q}(m)\,.

Now, for integers l𝑙l such that r2​(l)=0subscript𝑟2𝑙0r_{2}(l)=0 we have ρq​(l)=0subscript𝜌𝑞𝑙0\rho_{q}(l)=0 no matter what the value of q𝑞q is, and thus they do not make any contribution to the sum 𝒮q​(x)subscript𝒮𝑞𝑥\mathcal{S}_{q}(x), while those for which r2​(l)≠0subscript𝑟2𝑙0r_{2}(l)\neq 0 will have a larger contribution as q𝑞q grows due to the presence of r2​q​(⋅)subscript𝑟2𝑞⋅r_{2q}(\cdotp) in ρq​(⋅)subscript𝜌𝑞⋅\rho_{q}(\cdotp). Hence, ρq​(⋅)subscript𝜌𝑞⋅\rho_{q}(\cdotp) viewed as a function of q𝑞q will exhibit higher spikes as q𝑞q increases, making the task of obtaining Ω±subscriptΩplus-or-minus\Omega_{\pm} estimates for the error term ℰq​(x)subscriptℰ𝑞𝑥\mathcal{E}_{q}(x) much harder. This is in sharp contrast to the case of counting lattice points in Euclidean balls, where the function rk​(⋅)subscript𝑟𝑘⋅r_{k}(\cdotp) exhibits more of a regular behavior as the dimension k𝑘k increases, and as soon as k≥4𝑘4k\geq 4 one has a complete solution to the lattice point counting problem in this case.
